comment.body: can you add response to reproduce the issue

issue.title: Viewport addon to render multiple sizes at once
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe**
When updating component styles many time it gets fixed in one viewport but breaks in another. After every change, switching between viewports to verify everything is tedious.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Let user select multiple sizes in the Viewport Addon menu so the component rendered in Canvas can be worked upon considering all important breakpoints.

This problem becomes even more exemplified when Container Queries enter the picture. Since that brings responsiveness at component level instead of window level, devs would want to see whether their design system component can work across different container sizes and not just discrete window breakpoints.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Open Storybook in multiple windows with different viewport values and stack them side by side. Although working on single screen with editor open is very problematic and multiple browser windows would increase CPU load as well.

**Are you able to assist to bring the feature to reality?**
yes, I can...

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

comment.body: this would be an amazing feature

pull_request.body:
<!-- If your PR is related to an issue, provide the number(s) above; if it resolves multiple issues, be sure to break them up (e.g. "closes #1000, closes #1001"). -->

<!--

Thank you for contributing to Storybook! Please submit all PRs to the `next` branch unless they are specific to the current release. Storybook maintainers cherry-pick bug and documentation fixes into the `main` branch as part of the release process, so you shouldn't need to worry about this. For additional guidance: https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/contribute/how-to-contribute

-->


## What I did

<!-- Briefly describe what your PR does -->

I have fix the typo that was seen in the files of `docs` and `code` folder

```pseudo
slighty > slightly
addional > additional
reasearch > research
modifcation > modification
essense > essence
Utilties > Utilities
ammount > amount
```

comment.body:
**🚨 Potential security issues detected.** Learn more about [Socket for GitHub ↗︎](https://socket.dev?utm_medium=gh) To accept the risk, merge this PR and you will not be notified again.
Issue Package Version Note Source
New author vue-hot-reload-api 2.3.4
  • New Author: soda
  • Previous Author: yyx990803
  • @storybook/preset-vue-webpack@0.0.0-use.local, @storybook/vue-webpack5@0.0.0-use.local via code/package.json
  • vue-loader@15.11.1 via code/frameworks/vue-webpack5/package.json
  • vue-loader@15.11.1 via code/presets/vue-webpack/package.json
New author vue-style-loader 4.1.3
  • New Author: soda
  • Previous Author: yyx990803
  • @storybook/preset-vue-webpack@0.0.0-use.local, @storybook/vue-webpack5@0.0.0-use.local via code/package.json
  • vue-loader@15.11.1 via code/frameworks/vue-webpack5/package.json
  • vue-loader@15.11.1 via code/presets/vue-webpack/package.json
### Next steps
What is new author?

A new npm collaborator published a version of the package for the first time. New collaborators are usually benign additions to a project, but do indicate a change to the security surface area of a package.

Scrutinize new collaborator additions to packages because they now have the ability to publish code into your dependency tree. Packages should avoid frequent or unnecessary additions or changes to publishing rights.

Take a deeper look at the dependency

Take a moment to review the security alert above. Review the linked package source code to understand the potential risk. Ensure the package is not malicious before proceeding. If you're unsure how to proceed, reach out to your security team or ask the Socket team for help at support [AT] socket [DOT] dev.

Remove the package

If you happen to install a dependency that Socket reports as Known Malware you should immediately remove it and select a different dependency. For other alert types, you may may wish to investigate alternative packages or consider if there are other ways to mitigate the specific risk posed by the dependency.

Mark a package as acceptable risk

To ignore an alert, reply with a comment starting with @SocketSecurity ignore followed by a space separated list of package-name@version specifiers. e.g. @SocketSecurity ignore foo@1.0.0 bar@* or ignore all packages with @SocketSecurity ignore-all

  • @SocketSecurity ignore vue-hot-reload-api@2.3.4
  • @SocketSecurity ignore vue-style-loader@4.1.3

issue.title: React: Upgrade `react-docgen` to 6.0.x and improve argTypes
issue.body:
Extends #22324 ## What I did **NOTE: This only applies to _VITE_ projects, not Webpack ones yet!!!** Extends #22324: - [x] Update `react-docgen` to 6.0.x - [x] Add support for fs resolver Followup: - [ ] Update webpack too Also improve argType generation: - [x] Add experimental support for converting `unions` of `literals` into `enum`, which generate proper controls - [x] Fix table summary types for array, object, and function ## How to test in your project To test this out in a React Vite TS project, install the canary version listed at the top of this PR into a project by manually updating its `package.json` to update all the `@storybook/*` packages from this monorepo: ``` "@storybook/react": "0.0.0-pr-23825-sha-7875282b", "@storybook/react-vite": "0.0.0-pr-23825-sha-7875282b", ... ``` Once you've installed the packages, edit `.storybook/main.ts` to contain: ``` typescript: { reactDocgen: 'react-docgen', }, ``` The behavior should be the same as before, but running `storybook dev` should be dramatically faster than before. If you run into issues, please comment on this PR! ## How to test in a development sandbox 1. Create a development sandbox in this branch, e.g. ``` yarn task --task sandbox --start-from auto --template react-vite/default-ts ``` 2. Edit `.storybook/main.ts` to contain: ``` typescript: { reactDocgen: 'react-docgen', }, ``` 3. Add a new file `starbucks-size.ts` in `src/stories` directory: ```ts export type StarbucksSize = 'tall' | 'grande' | 'venti'; ``` 4. Update the CLI-generated `Button.tsx` component with a new prop: ```ts /** * How large should the button be at Starbucks? */ starbucksSize?: StarbucksSize; ``` 5. Observe the result in the controls panel: ## Checklist Needs tests: - [ ] Make sure your changes are tested (stories and/or unit, integration, or end-to-end tests) ### 🦋 Canary release This pull request has been released as version [`0.0.0-pr-23825-sha-7875282b`](https://npmjs.com/package/@storybook/cli/v/0.0.0-pr-23825-sha-7875282b). Install it by pinning all your Storybook dependencies to that version.
More information | | | | --- | --- | | **Published version** | [`0.0.0-pr-23825-sha-7875282b`](https://npmjs.com/package/@storybook/cli/v/0.0.0-pr-23825-sha-7875282b) | | **Triggered by** | @shilman | | **Repository** | [storybookjs/storybook](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook) | | **Branch** | [`shilman/fix-react-docgen-enum`](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/tree/shilman/fix-react-docgen-enum) | | **Commit** | [`7875282b`](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/commit/7875282ba0dfebc4e5f6a59ead02e08c7e509d3a) | | **Datetime** | Tue Aug 22 10:30:44 UTC 2023 (`1692700244`) | | **Workflow run** | [5937622254](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/actions/runs/5937622254) | To request a new release of this pull request, mention the `@storybookjs/core` team. _core team members can create a new canary release [here](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/actions/workflows/canary-release-pr.yml) or locally with `gh workflow run --repo storybookjs/storybook canary-release-pr.yml --field pr=23825`_

comment.body:
First, great work on this excellent product!
Second, do you guys plan on migrating to v7.0 of docgen as released any time soon?

I tried running v7.0 (by npm override) with sb v7.5 and am getting unexpected and strange errors.

commits.message:

- [ ] If you are deprecating/removing a feature, make sure to update

## Checklist for Maintainers

- [ ] When this PR is ready for testing, make sure to add `ci:normal`, `ci:merged` or `ci:daily` GH label to it to run a specific set of sandboxes. The particular set of sandboxes can be found in `code/lib/cli/src/sandbox-templates.ts`
- [ ] Make sure this PR contains **one** of the labels below:
   <details>
     <summary>Available labels</summary>

     - `bug`: Internal changes that fixes incorrect behavior.
     - `maintenance`: User-facing maintenance tasks.
     - `dependencies`: Upgrading (sometimes downgrading) dependencies.
     - `build`: Internal-facing build tooling & test updates. Will not show up in release changelog.
     - `cleanup`: Minor cleanup style change. Will not show up in release changelog.
     - `documentation`: Documentation **only** changes. Will not show up in release changelog.
     - `feature request`: Introducing a new feature.
     - `BREAKING CHANGE`: Changes that break compatibility in some way with current major version.
     - `other`: Changes that don't fit in the above categories.
   
   </details>

### 🦋 Canary release

issue.title: [Bug]: Webpack fails to compile with `Module parse failed: Unexpected token (3:1051)`
issue.body:
**UPDATE**: We are waiting for an upstream fix at https://github.com/acornjs/acorn/issues/1253. In the meantime, the temporary workaround for this is to pin `acorn` in your `package.json`.

### Workaround

Use npm overrides/yarn resolutions to pin `acorn` to `8.10.0` (in `package.json`):

**npm:**
```json
  "overrides": {
    "acorn": "8.10.0"
  }
```

**yarn:**
```json
  "resolutions": {
     "acorn": "8.10.0"
   }
```

---

### Describe the bug

Within the past few hours seemingly all - upgraded - Webpack-based projects are failing with this error:

```
You may need an additional loader to handle the result of these loaders.
|             alias: "important",
|             inside: {
>               punctuation: /==+$|--+$/
|             }
|           }, {
```

```
File was processed with these loaders:
 * ./node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/src/tools/babel/webpack-loader.js
You may need an additional loader to handle the result of these loaders.
|           },
|           arrow: {
>             pattern: /=>/,
|             alias: "operator"
|           }
```

Investigation suggest this is due to the release of `acorn@8.11.0` which happened [a few hours ago](https://www.npmjs.com/package/acorn?activeTab=versions): - There is a (non-storybook) reproduction here: https://github.com/acornjs/acorn/issues/1253

Upgrading Storybook or clearing your lock file could cause this.

### To Reproduce

Any Webpack-based sandbox (+Angular and Next.js) can reproduce this problem. Also clearing the lock file of an existing project (causing transitive dependencies to upgrade) will reproduce this. I've been able to reproduce this in a Storybook 7.1.1 project by just upgrading Webpack from `5.88.2` to `5.89.0`, not upgrading any of the Storybook dependencies.

### Additional context

This CI run shows the error: https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/storybookjs/storybook/62040/workflows/714253a5-5f50-4ab3-a47c-439ec9ae04c6/jobs/589782

issue.title: [Bug]: Webpack fails to compile with `Module parse failed: Unexpected token (3:1051)`
issue.body:
**UPDATE**: We are waiting for an upstream fix at https://github.com/acornjs/acorn/issues/1253. In the meantime, the temporary workaround for this is to pin `acorn` in your `package.json`.

### Workaround

Use npm overrides/yarn resolutions to pin `acorn` to `8.10.0` (in `package.json`):

**npm:**

```json
    "acorn": "8.10.0"
  }
```

**yarn:**
```json

     "acorn": "8.10.0"
   }
```

---

### Describe the bug

Within the past few hours seemingly all - upgraded - Webpack-based projects are failing with this error:

```
You may need an additional loader to handle the result of these loaders.
|             alias: "important",
|             inside: {
>               punctuation: /==+$|--+$/
|             }
|           }, {
```

```
File was processed with these loaders:
 * ./node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/src/tools/babel/webpack-loader.js
You may need an additional loader to handle the result of these loaders.
|           },
|           arrow: {
>             pattern: /=>/,
|             alias: "operator"
|           }
```

Investigation suggest this is due to the release of `acorn@8.11.0` which happened [a few hours ago](https://www.npmjs.com/package/acorn?activeTab=versions): - There is a (non-storybook) reproduction here: https://github.com/acornjs/acorn/issues/1253

Upgrading Storybook or clearing your lock file could cause this.

### To Reproduce

Any Webpack-based sandbox (+Angular and Next.js) can reproduce this problem. Also clearing the lock file of an existing project (causing transitive dependencies to upgrade) will reproduce this. I've been able to reproduce this in a Storybook 7.1.1 project by just upgrading Webpack from `5.88.2` to `5.89.0`, not upgrading any of the Storybook dependencies.

### Additional context

This CI run shows the error: https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/storybookjs/storybook/62040/workflows/714253a5-5f50-4ab3-a47c-439ec9ae04c6/jobs/589782

comment.body:
Issue is resolved: https://github.com/acornjs/acorn/issues/1253#issuecomment-1782480979

Please upgrade acorn from `8.11.x` to `8.11.2`.
